body: As far as I remember, KafkaBasedLogTest never passed on my machine. I got this branch, and the tests passed 5 times.

It occurred to me that we don't need to backport this as we don't use the Java classes to serialise the responses in 0.9.0. That will only be done when https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/640 is merged.
This is blocked by https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/649

Merged to both branches.

Thanks for fixing these issues.
The change LGTM but is a bit larger than what I feel comfortable without a JIRA (it includes added assertions to a test). Can you open a JIRA, describe the changes and link here?
@gwenshap, I can file a JIRA sure. Note that the assertions are for verifying the MockClient change (it doesn't affect any prod code).
LGTM as well. I am fine either with a JIRA or not, so its your call :)
@guozhangwang @gwenshap Thanks both for reviewing. I filed the JIRA and updated the PR title.
+1. looks good.
@eribeiro Doesn't build for me since `Set` is still used in this file. Otherwise LGTM.
@gwen @guozhangwang @junrao @ewencp Any chance any of you could review this?
LGTM. Waiting for Jenkins to pass.
@junrao Ping for another look. Jenkins failures seem not relevant and we have a separate ticket tracking it.

@granthenke Yes, I ran into the same issue while trying to migrate controlled shutdown to `Selector`/`NetworkClient` (and that is why the BlockingChannel implementation still exists).

I am not sure what the policy is regarding how many versions we support. It may be worth sending an email to the mailing list asking about this.
LGTM

@granthenke Started reviewing this, but then realized -- what is the story around compatibility in this patch? It seems like we're modifying a bunch of behavior around exceptions in public APIs (old consumer, simple consumer). Since we're throwing a completely different exception hierarchy and user code is probably going to be catching the old errors, isn't this going to break a ton of user code (and require major overhauls of any exception handling to compile against the new version)?

I definitely like the idea of getting rid of huge swaths of redundant code, just not sure all the change here will be safe. Another intermediate step I could imagine working is to replace as much as possible in the server where it is safe, leave the existing exceptions in place just for the clients, and then we'll be setup to eventually remove the entire client code and exceptions whenever we deprecate and then remove the old clients.

@ZoneMayor Thanks for looking into this. I think this reasoning makes sense.

In the current producer version we have already deprecated METADATA_FETCH_TIMEOUT_CONFIG and BLOCK_ON_BUFFER_FULL_CONFIG, so in order to eliminate this issue instead of just reducing its likelihood we could choose to not set any of these two, and instead set MAX_BLOCK_MS_CONFIG to Long.MAX_VALUE so that the producer will be blocked forever if there is not enough data.
@granders Please review.

Running tests here:
http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/312
:+1: The reasoning also makes sense to me.
Merged to both branches.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
Merged to trunk.
Filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2977 for the test failure, which is not relevant to this PR.
Isn't this scenario covered by the `requestUpdate()` in `Sender.run()`  which checks whether there are unknown leaders when there is data to send?
@guozhangwang KAFKA-2959 is a subtask of KAFKA-1927.
Hi ~@guozhangwang  Thanks a lot for your comment, I make it to be expected exception, please help check again ~thanks
Rebases and fixes compiler error in #263 (@eribeiro remains the author of the commit). @ewencp, fixed the issue you pointed out in the original PR.
nice! LGTM

@ewencp @ijuma @hachikuji I updated the PR covering the review comments. The changes are less aggressive in favor of compatibility. I also update the jira and comments to reflect that.

This PR replaces all usage of ErrorMapping.scala and deprecated exceptions server side, and utilizes Errors.java client side wherever there is no incompatibility impact.
@rajinisivaram I think we also need a test on the consumer side that ensures we always set subscribed or assigned topics to never expire.
@eribeiro We've resolved this (with attribution maintained) in https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/659. When you have a chance, could you close out this PR?

Thanks for the PR @ZoneMayor.

I am not sure about the approach, it seems a bit of a hack to create a root project for the sole purpose of depending on slf4j-log4j12.

Looking at the output below, there are two problems:
- We depend on slf4j 1.7.6 and some other library depends on slf4j 1.7.10

This is relatively straightforward: we should bump our version to 1.7.13 (the latest) and we should exclude the transitive dependency from the library that's bringing 1.7.10.
- `kafka-run-class` builds the classpath by adding the dependent libraries of several subprojects, so we end up including slf4j-log4j12 multiple times.

This is a bit odd and it seems like a hack. I am not familiar with why we follow that approach instead of building a classpath that is appropriate to the class being started (ie the classpath for the project it is part of). @ewencp, do you know?

With the current approach, it's a bit hard to fix the issue (we can't filter duplicates trivially when constructing the classpath because we are relying on wildcards to build the classpath - in order not to exceed command-line length limits on certain platforms).

Warnings:

``` sh
SLF4J: Found binding in [jar:file:/Users/ijuma/src/kafka/core/build/dependant-libs-2.10.6/slf4j-log4j12-1.7.10.jar!/org/slf4j/impl/StaticLoggerBinder.class]
SLF4J: Found binding in [jar:file:/Users/ijuma/src/kafka/core/build/dependant-libs-2.10.6/slf4j-log4j12-1.7.6.jar!/org/slf4j/impl/StaticLoggerBinder.class]

SLF4J: Found binding in [jar:file:/Users/ijuma/src/kafka/connect/runtime/build/dependant-libs/slf4j-log4j12-1.7.6.jar!/org/slf4j/impl/StaticLoggerBinder.class]

```

Thanks for the explanation @ewencp. I agree that we should not duplicate the logic in `kafka-run-class` and your suggestion is similar to what I was thinking.

@ZoneMayor, given what was discussed, this turns out to be a bigger task than what the JIRA indicates. And there are some details that need to be worked out. Are you interested in exploring a solution along the lines of what @ewencp described?
@granthenke Yeah.... Just noticed that. Thanks for the reminding.
LGTM. On a separate jira we may want to add systests for scenarios like this.

LGTM.
@dajac Are you interested in rebasing this? If so, I will quickly review. If not, I am happy to pick it up.

@apovzner Test itself looks good to me, just suggested some tweaks to the code and have a question about whether we need all variants. I'm convinced it works reliably -- I see multiple successes on Jenkins and ran it successfully a few times locally.
@apovzner Not much to add after Ben and Ewen's comments. Overall looks good; I agree parse_describe_topic could be refactored elsewhere, and that PLAINTEXT is likely enough.
LGTM.

We add a KWindowedTable as a third citizen in addition to KStream and KTable, which can be generated from windowed stream-stream join and stream aggregations. The main reasons for adding this interface are the following:
1. Windowed tables generated from a windowing definition cannot be directly written back to a Kafka topic: users have to decide either encode the window id into the key or value.
2. We want to support a specific left join for windowed tables that allow shifting windows when joining two windowed tables, e.g. comparing the current aggregate results with history windowed aggregates a week ago.
3. Stream to windowed-table join needs to be handled differently from stream to table join.

Admittedly adding this third class makes the whole DSL a bit too fat and cumbersome, but we have not came a better solution to the above three approaches. So feedbacks and thoughts on tangling the above three issues in order to simplify the APIs are more than welcomed.
LGTM
@granders Love the goal of the patch, just have a few questions re: the implementation.

@guozhangwang Ping for review. I replaced the consumed/fetched variables with a single position. This seems to work fine with pre-fetching and it simplifies the code. Have a look and let me know if I missed something.
LGTM, thanks for getting rid of the trash piling up under `core/target/` :)
Yes, well spotted. Clearly the original code was ported from a Maven project and no-one noticed.
Merged to trunk.

@granthenke One minor comment, but this looks good as long as it covers the intended scope. Just want to make sure we're on the same page -- the goal we've settled on for the parent JIRA KAFKA-1927 is just to get the old requests out of KafkaApis, right? I quick search and it looks like there are quite a few uses of `OffsetRequest` left, but they are all in the old consumer, tools, or tests.
@ijuma , I have lots of interest to work this out~, and will raise idea later
I was a little confused with boxing/unboxing of long/Long and ==/equals, but the updates look ok.
Michal tested this branch and it fixes the issue he was seeing. Is there a way we can write a test (system or otherwise) that captures the problem?
@ewencp Thank you for the review. I have made the updates and also added a test for the consumer side.

@ewencp All the remaining usages are while interacting with the simple consumer or testing serialization of the old message format. The goal of these patches is to remove the usage from server side code and then once that is done KAFKA-2075 is the final clean up. 

There is no task there to remove the old Scala producer/consumers, but I think that is the task that would clean a lot of this up too. I can add that to the list.
@ewencp I have created KAFKA-2982, which I can do now, to track marking all the old clients/classes as deprecated, and KAFKA-2983 to track removing the old clients and the code tied to their usage.

@granthenke LGTM. As Ismael noted in KAFKA-2982, you might need to split that JIRA between old producer and old consumer given the significantly different schedules. Sadly, I think that means we'll have to hold on to this older code for quite a bit longer.

@ijuma I was thinking about that. I think the main reason we didn't catch it in our system tests is that we weren't looking for it. In our current tests, we check after every rebalance that at least some messages are consumed, but we should strengthen that to assert that some messages _from each partition_ are consumed. If it seems reasonable, I'll open a separate JIRA for this.
@ewencp Thanks for the review! I will continue to follow up on the client/cleanup jiras. This and many of my other PRs are more or less intertwined. So when one gets in, I will rebase the others.
That sounds good to me @hachikuji
LGTM. Should we change the default to be a much higher value to reduce the issues?
@ewencp Rebased based on #663. This patch is very similar.
@dajac Are you interested in rebasing this?
@ymatsuda Ping for reviews.
